title: 112_s3581
content: MODIFICATIONS TO CARBON DIOXIDE SEQUESTRATION CREDIT. Modifications to the carbon dioxide sequestration credit include amendments to the allocation and certification of credit under section 45Q of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The limitation specifies that no credit shall be allowed for excess carbon dioxide captured by carbon capture equipment at a qualified facility beyond the national limitation of 75,000,000 metric tons. The amendment to section 45Q of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 sets a national limitation of 75,000,000 metric tons for the credit for carbon dioxide sequestration. The Secretary is required to establish procedures for allocating this limitation to projects and certifying them by July 1, 2013. The amendment to section 45Q of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 establishes procedures for allocating the national limitation of 75,000,000 metric tons for carbon capture projects. Applicants must submit applications to the Secretary for certification, with priority given based on the date of application submission. Priority for certification of carbon capture projects is determined based on the date of application submission. Earlier applications receive higher priority, followed by concurrent applicants, and then projects with earlier construction commencement dates. Priority for certification of carbon capture projects is determined based on the date of application submission. Projects with earlier construction commencement dates are given higher priority. The Secretary allocates tonnage to applicants based on the amount requested and the rank of the application until the available tonnage is exhausted. Applicants with no or partial allocation retain their ranking and may receive forfeited or recaptured tonnage. The Secretary allocates tonnage to carbon capture projects based on application submission date and construction commencement date priority. Projects with no or partial allocation retain their ranking and may receive forfeited tonnage. The Secretary cannot allocate more tonnage than the projected capture amount in a 10-year period or under a written disposal contract for secure storage. Qualified carbon dioxide projected to be captured at a facility must be subject to a disposal contract for secure storage or have a disposal plan by the applicant. The allocation for a project is reduced by the amount of carbon dioxide captured before August 1, 2013, for which a credit was allowed. Certification is required for the process. The allocation for a project is reduced by the amount of carbon dioxide captured before August 1, 2013, for which a credit was allowed. Certification is required for using carbon capture equipment at a qualified facility. The Secretary requires an application for certification for projects using carbon capture equipment at a qualified facility. The application must be submitted within 6 months of receiving an allocation and not earlier than the construction start date. The construction start date is defined as the first date of significant physical work on the project or when 5% of the total project cost is incurred. The Secretary may revoke a certification if an applicant makes materially inaccurate representations or fails to timely place carbon capture equipment in service for the project. The Secretary may revoke a certification if carbon capture equipment is not placed in service within specified timeframes after the allocation was issued for a new or modified industrial facility. In such cases, reallocation of the certification may occur. The Secretary may revoke a certification if carbon capture equipment is not placed in service within specified timeframes after allocation for a new or modified industrial facility. In such cases, reallocation of the certification may occur, with public disclosure requirements in place. The Secretary must publicly disclose any allocation, certification, revocation, or project ranking changes. An annual report summarizing credits allocated and available must be issued. Conforming amendments are made to section 45Q(c) of the Internal Revenue Code. A 10-year credit limitation is imposed in section 45Q(a). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a 10-year credit limitation for carbon capture equipment. The definition of carbon capture equipment is also updated. The definition of carbon capture equipment is updated in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include equipment that captures and pressurizes qualified carbon dioxide. The credit for capturing qualified carbon dioxide is allowed to the taxpayer who performs the capture. The credit for capturing qualified carbon dioxide is allowed to the taxpayer who captures and disposes of it in a compliant manner, with an option to allow the credit to the person disposing of the carbon dioxide. The credit for capturing qualified carbon dioxide is allowable to the person disposing of it in compliance with regulations. Conforming amendments are made to sections 45Q(a) and 45Q(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Rules relating to credit recapture are also amended in section 45Q(d). Section 45Q of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to redesignate paragraphs and specify that regulations apply only to carbon dioxide captured after a certain date. These changes apply to carbon dioxide captured after July 31, 2013.
